metadata.description: Comprehensive accessibility keywords system for analyzing parkrun course suitability across 8 different mobility types. Uses impact scoring from -50 to +50, where each mobility type starts at 50/100 (neutral) and keywords add/subtract points to reach a final score out of 100. v3.2: Added racing chair maneuverability challenges (narrow paths + tight corners = -40), increased wide path bonus for racing chairs (+10 to +20), added racing-friendly features (long straights, gentle corners).

mobility_types.racing_chair: Racing chair - narrow wheels, low to ground, designed for speed on smooth surfaces
mobility_types.day_chair: Day chair - standard wheelchair for daily use, moderate off-road capability
mobility_types.off_road_chair: Off-road/sports chair - wider tires, better suspension, designed for rough terrain
mobility_types.handbike: Handbike - three-wheeled hand-powered cycle, good on most surfaces
mobility_types.frame_runner: Frame runner/RaceRunner - three-wheeled frame with saddle and body plate, user propels with feet, requires stable surface
mobility_types.walking_frame: Walking frame/walker - four-legged frame for stability, slow pace, requires even surface
mobility_types.crutches: Crutches (forearm or underarm) - requires upper body strength, challenging on uneven surfaces
mobility_types.walking_stick: Walking stick/cane - single or quad cane, provides light support, requires relatively even surface

scoring_system.methodology: Start at 50/100 (50% chance). Add positive impacts for good features, subtract for barriers. Perfect course reaches 100, impossible course reaches 0.

metadata.notes: Individual experiences may vary. Weather conditions can significantly impact scores. Unknown factors score 0 (no impact).

smooth_surfaces.notes: Ideal for all mobility aid users - smooth, predictable, stable surface. Critical for walking frames and frame runners.

packed_surfaces.notes: Good if truly firm. Walking frames struggle with small wheels. Frame runners need solid footing.

loose_surfaces.notes: Major barrier for most users. Frame runners lose foot traction. Walking frames sink. Nearly impossible for racing chairs.

grass_surfaces.notes: Highly condition-dependent. Dry short grass manageable for some. Wet/long grass very difficult for all. Walking frames struggle significantly.

trail_surfaces.notes: Off-road chairs designed for this. Very difficult for racing chairs and walking frames. Frame runners need stable footing. NOTE: 'athletics track' is NOT a trail surface - removed generic 'track' keyword to avoid false positives.

mixed_surfaces.notes: Surface transitions challenging for wheeled users and walking aids. Need to assess specific mix.

steep_elevation.notes: STEEP hills are significant barriers. Generic mentions of 'uphill' or 'downhill' removed - wheelchair users often enjoy moderate hills for workout/speed. Only penalize clearly steep/challenging elevation changes.

undulating_terrain.notes: Moderate repeated elevation changes. More challenging for walking frames. Can be enjoyable workout for wheelchair users if not too steep.

flat_terrain.notes: Critical for walking frames and frame runners. Allows consistent pace and reduced fatigue.

gentle_slopes.notes: Gentle slopes can provide good workout variation for wheelchair users without being a barrier. Slight negative for walking frames only.

physical_barriers.notes: Steps are impossible for wheeled aids without assistance. Gates that must be navigated THROUGH are barriers - passing/rolling past gates is fine. Major barriers for all.

maneuverability_challenges.notes: CRITICAL for racing chairs: narrow paths + tight corners = impossible due to wide wheelbase, long length, and turning circle of a truck. Racing chairs have very limited steering. Also challenging for handbikes (3-wheeled, wide). Minor issue for day chairs. Not a barrier for walking aids.

surface_hazards.notes: Major trip/fall risk for walking aids. Wheels catch on roots. Crutch tips catch in cracks. Serious safety concern.

wet_conditions.notes: CRITICAL IMPACT. Frame runners lose all foot traction. Walking aids major slip risk. Walking frames get stuck. Transforms courses into dangerous.

seasonal_factors.notes: Leaves hide hazards. Ice/snow extremely dangerous for all. Fall risk severe.

path_width.notes: CRITICAL for racing chairs and handbikes: wide paths allow overtaking and maneuvering the wide wheelbase. Frame runners and walking frames also need width for turning. Increased impact for racing chairs from +10 to +20.

racing_friendly_features.notes: Racing chairs excel on courses with gentle corners, long straights, and space to build speed. Wide turning radius is needed. Handbikes also benefit. Less relevant for walking aids.

surface_condition.notes: Good maintenance benefits all users. Reduces hazards and improves predictability.

accessibility_features.notes: Explicit accessibility mentions are very positive indicators. Shows consideration for mobility aid users.

good_conditions.notes: Fast courses usually mean smooth surfaces and flat terrain. Frame runners can achieve good speeds on these.

lap_indicators.notes: Multi-lap allows users to assess conditions after first lap and decide whether to continue. Particularly helpful for walking frames.

explicit_barriers.notes: Explicit warnings should be taken very seriously. Off-road chairs may still manage. Others likely impossible.

unique_surfaces.notes: Sand extremely difficult for all (wheels sink, feet slip, walking aids sink). Metal grating dangerous for crutches and frame runner feet. Boardwalks generally good if flat.

distance_factors.notes: 5K is significant distance for walking frames (45-90+ minutes, high fatigue). Important to consider endurance.

difficulty_indicators.notes: 'Challenging' courses much harder for those with fatigue conditions. Upper body fatigue for crutches, leg fatigue for frame runners.

inclusive_language.notes: Explicit confirmation that slower paces are welcomed. Reduces anxiety about 'holding others up'. Critical for walking frame users.
